meanings.definition: To take possession of a mortgaged property due to the borrower's failure to keep up with payments.
meanings.sent1: The bank foreclosed on the house when the owner couldn't pay the mortgage.
meanings.sent2: The bank had to foreclose on the property after the owner missed several payments.
meanings.sent3: The bank foreclosed on the house, turning it into a real estate bargain for someone else.
meanings.sent4: The bank's decision to foreclose on the property left the previous owner feeling defeated.
meanings.sent5: The image of the bank seizing the house in a foreclosure was a stark reminder of financial struggles.

meanings.definition: To prevent someone from doing something by taking action in advance.
meanings.sent1: The security guard foreclosed any attempts to enter the restricted area.
meanings.sent2: The teacher had to foreclose any cheating during the exam.
meanings.sent3: The clever detective foreclosed the suspect's escape plan with a clever trap.
meanings.sent4: The quick intervention foreclosed any chance of the situation escalating further.
meanings.sent5: The timely warning foreclosed any potential dangers from arising.

meanings.definition: To rule out or exclude a possibility.
meanings.sent1: The detective had to foreclose the theory of the suspect's innocence.
meanings.sent2: The evidence presented in court foreclosed any doubts about the defendant's guilt.
meanings.sent3: The scientist had to foreclose the idea of life on Mars due to lack of evidence.
meanings.sent4: The logical reasoning foreclosed any other possible explanations for the phenomenon.
meanings.sent5: The conclusive results foreclosed any room for uncertainty in the experiment.
